intro: Pleiotaxis huillensis subsp. argentea, commonly known as the silver pleiotaxis, is a rare and endemic species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is characterized by its distinctive silver-gray foliage, which results from dense pubescence covering the leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils at high altitudes, often in mountainous environments. Its flowers are small and clustered, usually in inflorescences that bloom in late spring or early summer. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
